Doctor. Doctor, wake up.

That wave of heat.

Okay. What about you?
Well, I'd better go and have a word with the Brigadier. He's probably bursting a blood vessel by now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates puts Jo into Bessie, while the Doctor drives to the barrier on the motorcycle. In the church cavern, the Master, in his red robe, orders Bok back to his pedestal and stands before the altar.

Dialogue.Line: Twenty thousand pounds of UNIT money gone up in a puff of smoke.
You've got the mind of an accountant, Lethbridge Stewart. So, this is your heat barrier, is it?
Yes, and I advise you to keep your distance.
Yes?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws a small stone into the barrier. It disintegrates in a flash.

Dialogue.Line: Hmm. Even rock.
Wood, rock, four inch armour plate. You name it, we've tried it. It's impenetrable.
A hasty and inaccurate assessment, Brigadier. Tell me, have you got enough cable to reach those high tension pylons over there.
Yes, we should have. Why?
We'll need at least ten thousand volts to get through this lot.
All right, I'll lay things on.
Good. Only please hurry, we may have very little time left.
Sergeant Osgood?
Sir?
You'd better come and listen to the Doctor. You've got to build the wretched thing.
What's the principle, sir?
Negative diathermy, Sergeant. Buffer the molecular movement of the air with the reverse phase short waves. It's quite simple.
Simple? It's impossible.
Yes, well, according to classical aerodynamics, it's impossible for a bumblebee to fly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is getting an invocation ceremony underway.

Dialogue.Line: By the power of earth, by the power of air, by the power of fire eternal and the waters of the deep, I conjure thee and charge thee, Azal. Arise, arise at my command, Azal. Arise, arise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo is in the bed now.

Dialogue.Line: The cavern. He said the danger was in the cavern.
Just lie still, my dear. Try and relax.
But the
This won't hurt.
But the Doctor. I must help him find the Master!
Take it easy, Jo. As soon as he gets back, we'll all go and sort the Master out. Now don't worry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Doctor Reeves sedates Jo.

Dialogue.Line: But we must go now. There's no time to
That's better. A few hours sleep and she'll be as right as rain.
Heho evoway! Heho evoway Azal! I will speak with you. Show yourself!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The temperature in the cavern plummets as something that was very small rips the energy from the air in order to become very large again. The Master falls to the ground, staring up at what he has summoned. Tremors ripple through the earth all the way to the barrier, and wake Jo.
Glass and furniture goes flying as the church bells are shaken to ring in the tower.

Dialogue.Line: The demon! If he comes out, we shall all die!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: UNIT's equivalent of REME have been busy, and are loading equipment into the back of a Land Rover.

Dialogue.Line: Now get a move on with the heat exchanger. We've got to get it charged and through this barrier and down to the village before it's too late.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master is crawling on the floor.

Dialogue.Line: No! No, back! Back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He grabs a metal candle holder and brandishes it.

Dialogue.Line: In the name of the Unspeakable One, back! Nakmia sayamat. Back!
Where am I? The cavern. I must get to the cavern.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo opens the bedroom door and hears voices from the bar below.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I'm going down to the cavern to see what's going on.
You can't, dear boy, the Doctor told us to stay here.
Well, anyway, we can't just leave Jo here alone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo looks out of the front window, then the back, and climbs out onto the flat roof of an extension building that has a convenient ladder propped against it. She climbs down to the ground and walks around the building, where Bessie is parked out front. Checking that she is in the clear, she heads to the church.

Dialogue.Line: I'm going to see what's happening.
Oh, you can't, it's too dangerous.
Look, the Doctor told us to stop here, sir.
Oh, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood is trying to connect up the Doctor's device as soldiers roll out drums of cable.

Dialogue.Line: No, man, no. You're trying to channel the entire output of the National Power Complex through one transistor. Reverse it.
Reverse what?
Reverse the polarity.
Look, we'd get along much faster if we knew what we were doing.
Yes, I couldn't agree with you more, Sergeant. Now let's concentrate, shall we?
Right, I've fixed with Nuton for the power to be off for fifteen minutes. Ready to link up?
No, sir.
Well, when will you be ready, for heaven's sake?
About next Christmas, I shouldn't wonder. At a rough estimate, of course.
Look, if you push ten thousand volts through this lash up you'll blow it anyway!
Just do as you're told, Sergeant. The Doctor knows what he's doing.
Right, sir. Right, Jenkins, have you got that junction box lined up?
Do you know what you're doing?
My dear chap, I can't wait to find out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something with hairy thighs and cloven hooves for feet is towering over the Master. It's voice echoes around the enclosed space.

Dialogue.Line: Speak!
I am the Master. I called you here.
That I know. Tell me why you now call me.
Give me your knowledge and your power.
Why?
So that I may rule these primitives on Earth here, and help them to fulfill your plan.
You are not one of their kind.
No, I'm superior to them. That's why I should be their leader.
There is another here of your race.
He has been destroyed.
No, he lives. I would speak with him.
I think not!
Take care, creature! With your few pitiful grains of knowledge, you have summoned me here, but I am not your slave and you are not immortal.
Forgive me, Mighty One, forgive me. Nevertheless, I claim that which is rightfully mine.
Your mind is superior to mankind's, and your will is stronger.
Then I am to be your choice?
I shall consider. Now leave.
But you will come again?
I shall appear but once more, so be warned. There is danger. My race destroys its failures. Remember Atlantis.
Yes, but surely I
Be silent! I am the last of the Daemons. This planet smells to me of failure. It may be that I shall destroy it. You still wish me to come once more?
I do.
Very well. Now go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master runs up into the vestry as heat surges through the building, given off as Azal shrinks itself again. The energy given off rushes out through the village as a hot wind, blowing Jo against the churchyard wall and throwing Yates to the floor in the pub.

Dialogue.Line: It's going. I must get back. The next time could be the finish. Sergeant Osgood, can you operate that machine now?
Well, I'm not quite sure.
Yes, well, you'll have to. We may have very little time left.
Wait, Doctor. I still don't understand how you lock the pulse generator to the feedback circuit. They'll never be in phase.
Well, of course they won't. That's the whole point.
Well, how do you do it then?
Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear. All right, I'll explain once again. Only this time, please listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Azal returns to the decorated stone and the heat dissipates.

Dialogue.Line: Jo. Jo! Jo!
You all right, Jo?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates sees the open back window.

Dialogue.Line: Little idiot!
You all right?
More or less. How about you?
Shaken, I'll admit.
Jo's gone. Out of the window. I'm going after her.
Well, do you know where she is, sir?
I know all right. She'll have gone to the cavern.
No!
Trust her.
Look, when the Doc gets back, tell him what's happened.
Look, be careful, sir. I don't want you to cop it like I did.
Huh, not if I can help it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates leaves. Miss Hawthorne has poured two stiff drinks.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant?
Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bert the landlord is getting his orders.

Dialogue.Line: And make sure you do the job properly. The Doctor's been in my way for far too long. You know, I was very foolish to speak with Azal alone. Next time, I shall use the full ceremony. Every possible member of the coven must be present. If I'm going to control Azal, I need every ounce of power I can summon up. Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates hides behind a gravestone as Bert leaves the church and drives off in his car. Yates runs into the church. Jo collapses by the wall.
The Doctor has drawn a circuit diagram on the motorbike's windshield.

Dialogue.Line: And it comes out here. Right?
Right. I think.
Good grief, man, it's as simple as Einstein's Special theory of Relativity.
We'll manage, Doctor.
Good. And when you get that thing finished, bring it through the barrier and down to the village at once, all right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor rides off on the motorbike.

Dialogue.Line: Do you know, Sergeant, I sometimes wish I worked in a bank. Right, at the double there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo wakes on the ground and briefly has second thoughts about her plan. Then she runs round the church, into the vestry and down the stairs. The sight of the gargoyle in his niche makes her cry out, then someone puts their hand over her mouth.

Dialogue.Line: Shush. They're in and out all the time.
Mike, what
Why didn't you stay in bed?
I had to find out what was going on.
You're an idiot. This place is alive with booby traps.
What?
Spells, elementals, the Doctor's forcefields.
Where, where are they?
All over. Here, I'll show you. Give me that book there or something.
Yes.
Now watch this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He throws the register onto the decorated stone, and it flies apart, pages going everywhere.

Dialogue.Line: It's a trick. A horrible conjuring trick.
You think so? Remember Benton? Now come on, let's get out of. Shush!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hide behind a railing as someone in black surplice comes in and puts candles on the altar. Meanwhile, Bert is taking pot shots at the Doctor as he rides towards the village. The Doctor falls off the bike and runs for the trees. Bert follows. In the cavern, an ornate dagger has been placed on the altar.

Dialogue.Line: Mike, I'm scared.
Don't worry. The Doc'll be here soon, and Benton knows we're here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But Benton can't tell anyone else.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Greyhound. This is Trap Three. Do you read me? Over. Hello, Greyhound, Greyhound. Do you read me? Over.
I've bought you a nice cuppa, Sergeant. I hope you like china.
For goodness sake, Miss Hawthorne.
What's the matter? Don't you like tea?

Something's gone badly wrong. We've no idea what's happening to Miss Grant and the Captain, the Doctor should be back here by now, I can't get through to the Brigadier and you're nattering on about tea.
You must learn the art of waiting, Sergeant. The Doctor will come, or else he won't, and that's all that can be said. Now, milk or lemon?
Hello, Greyhound, Greyhound. Do you read me? Over.
Sergeant?
Sir?
Is it you making that horrible racket? I can't get a thing through. The air's thick with it.
Yes, sir, it is. Testing, you see, sir. This is fascinating. It's not right yet but even on the battery, it's pumping it out. It's a sort of controlled resonance frequency you see, sir.
Yes, well, never mind the mumbo-jumbo. Keep the wretched thing switched off until it's ready.
I'm sorry, sir, I can't. I must finish the tests.
Well, how long are you going to be?
About a minute, sir. I've got the hang of it now. (Bang, and Osgood has a sooty face) Half an hour, sir. At least.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone is hammering at the door. The Master answers it.

Dialogue.Line: Magister, I'm sorry.
The Doctor got away.
How could you know that? Well, yes he did. You see, what happened
Excuses waste time. Where is he?
I lost him in the woods. Expect he's making his way back to the village by now.
Then we must see that he is given a suitable welcome, mustn't we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The radios are working again.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter with you, Benton? I want to speak to the Doctor. Over.
But I, but I thought he was still with you, sir. Over.
No, he left here oh, a good forty minutes ago. Hasn't

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Miss Hawthorne looks up from her crocheting.

Dialogue.Line: He turned up yet?
Well, no, sir. Not a sign of him. Do you suppose he's all right, sir? Over.
Maybe he's piled up that wretched motorbike.
Do you want me to go and look for him, sir? Over.
No, better give him a bit longer. But if he does turn up will you tell him that we're running into a bit of trouble with our feedback phasing. Is that right, Osgood?
Yes, sir.
Yes, that's it, Benton. Tell him that, will you? Over and out.
That's it then.
More waiting, Sergeant.
Yes, well, the Captain and Miss Grant should have been back ages ago, and the Doctor seems to have disappeared completely. Look, I'm going to go and have a nose around out there.
You stay where you are. I'll go and look for them.
I'm sorry, ma'am. Would you please do as you're told.
Anyone in sight?
No, just a few villagers. Could you tell the Doctor I've gone to the cavern.
Wait. Listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Music starts up outside.

Dialogue.Line: Well, what do they thing they're doing?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Maypole is on the village green, and Morris Dancers with sticks lead by Bert in a 'tattered' coat are approaching. A housewife takes her little girl indoors and others close their windows. Villagers go to the pole and take the ribbons.

Dialogue.Line: Charming.
Yeah, they're round the twist, if you ask me.
But it's May day. We always have the Morris Dancers on May day. It's traditional.
Hey, look, there's the Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A second morris dance begins and the villagers begin to weave the ribbons round the pole. The Doctor is driven towards it by the Fool with his bladder on a stick.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, yes, most amusing.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bert directs the morris to encircle the Doctor with their sticks.

Dialogue.Line: Now please, let me pass. Frankly, any time I'd gladly join you but I

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is pushed to the ground.

Dialogue.Line: What on Earth is going on? What are you doing? What on Earth is this?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bert points his snub-nosed revolver at the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: You're being invited to join our May day revels, Doctor. I'm sure you don't want to disappoint us, or Mister Magister.
They seem to have stopped.
Yeah. Hey, what's happening? Well, that doesn't look very traditional.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: With sticks around his neck, the Doctor is hustled to the May pole where his hands are tied behind it.

Dialogue.Line: Look, I've got to go and help him.
No, you can't. There are too many of them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton opens the main door and is promptly attacked by a morris man. Benton takes a beating until Miss Hawthorne thumps the man over the head with her handbag.

Dialogue.Line: Did he hurt you?
What happened?
I hit him with my reticule. (crystal ball) On these occasions, the outcome's a certainty.
Very handy. Thank you.
I always carry it with me. No, Sergeant, wait. Look, I know these people. They're not wicked. Well, most of them anyway.
So?
So, it's up to us to explain to them how mistaken they are. Now, listen carefully.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is being tied to the pole with the ribbons.

Dialogue.Line: The Master's planning to make slaves of you all. I'm the only one who has a chance of stopping him.
He's lying. He is the enemy. Mister Magister will care for you, give you everything you've ever wanted.
That's nonsense. All the Master will bring upon you is disaster!
He is the enemy! He's a black witch! A witch, do you hear? A witch and you've always known what you must do with a witch, haven't you?
Yeah, yeah.
Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live.
That's what they say.
Are you out of your mind?
Shut up. That's right, friends. Thou shalt not suffer a witch to live. Burn him!
Burn him!
Burn him! Burn him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The coven is meeting for the third summoning.

Dialogue.Line: Eoh evotay.
Eoh evotay.
As my will, so mote it be.
Nemas.

Harken to my voice, oh, Dark One, ancient and awful, supreme in artifice, bearer of power, be present here at my command and truly do my will. Ava, avara, agarbala, gar, gardoal, galdina! As my will, so mote it be.
As thy will, so mote it be!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok's eyes light up.
The Doctor is surrounded by faggots of wood up to the knees. Miss Hawthorne runs out of the pub as Thorpe lights a brand and hold it up.

Dialogue.Line: Now!
Stop! You will bring a terrible retribution upon yourselves if you persist.
Shut up, you silly old fool!
You would dare to harm the great Wizard Qui Quae Quod?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: For the non-Latin scholars, that's Who, Who, Who.

Dialogue.Line: Wizard?
You wouldn't listen to me before and now you're in the power of the Magister. You know I speak the truth.
Get on with it, man.
No, wait, listen to me. Under the Magister you have been frightened, injured, your property destroyed. Serve the great Qui Quae Quod. In him lies peace and great joy.
If he's such a great magician, let's see him untie himself.
You choose to mock the great Qui Quae Quod? Well, I will not.
Because you can't!
Give him a sign of your power, O mighty one!
What had you mind?
I know. That lamp. Shatter it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She points at a poor defenceless street light.

Dialogue.Line: Shatter it. Yes. Lamp, I order you to shatter!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And it does.

Dialogue.Line: You see? That could have been you. Now, all of you look at the, er, weathercock on the church tower?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hawthorne nods, and Benton takes aim with his service pistol, now fitted with a long silencer.

Dialogue.Line: Weathercock, now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The weathercock spins.

Dialogue.Line: He must be a magician. He is a magician!
Bert, drop that torch. You're beaten and you know it!
Am I?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton shoots the brand out of Bert's hand.

Dialogue.Line: There, that'll teach you. Daughter of light, would you kindly untie my bonds?
You don't scare me with a lot of daft tricks. Mister Magister has the real power.
His power is worth nothing in comparison.
Right. Well let's see if you can turn aside a bullet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton can't get a line on Bert now, villagers are in the way.

Dialogue.Line: I'll give you one more chance. Look behind you.
That's the oldest trick in the book.
Very well. Let my familiar spirit bring that car to me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bessie starts up and trundles over. Benton is impressed but Bert has his back to her.

Dialogue.Line: You don't frighten me, you know. Do you think I'm as stupid as this lot?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton leaves the pub as Bert finally hears Bessie behind him. He turns, fires a shot and Bessie gently runs him down.

Dialogue.Line: That's it. He is a god.
You really are a magician.
I'm sorry to disappoint you, madame, but I were, I'd hardly need your assistance in extricating me from this, this sacrificial gift wrapping.
How on Earth did you do that, Doctor?
Elemental, my dear Benton.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bert gets up and tries to run for it, but Benton pounces on him.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, no, you don't, chummie. We've all got a date with the Master, haven't we.
The last appearance, that's what the Doctor said.
I'm working as fast as I can.
Well, it doesn't seem to be fast enough. You have five minutes, Sergeant. Right, we're on our way in five minutes!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The villagers pick themselves up from the grass. A couple of men hold Bert securely.

Dialogue.Line: The third appearance.
In the cavern.
Where else?
We'd better get over there, hasn't we?
Wait, all of you.
See? This chap's frightened!
Well, of course I'm frightened. So should you be, and your friend Mister Magister.
Azal, welcome!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo hides behind Yates and his pistol.

Dialogue.Line: Bok, stop them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates shoots at Bok, but the bullets just bounce of the stone. Bok zaps an energy bolt at the wall and Yates surrenders.

Dialogue.Line: You are very wise, Captain. Prepare the girl in the ceremonial tabard. She will make a welcome addition to this sabbat.
No, please! Don't let me go! Mike, help me please! No, let me go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo is taken away. Yates is knocked out and dragged out of the cavern and tied up face down in the vestry.

Dialogue.Line: Now we're facing the greatest danger the world has ever known. Now, look, I've got to tell you the truth.
(sotto) Doctor, no.
(sotto) I've got to risk it.
What are you talking about?
I'm not a magician or a wizard or anything of the sort.
See! I told you!
But neither is the Master. I've tricked you, yes, but only to save you from him.
To save your own life, you mean.
Yes, of course, that too.
What? Well, there you are! Do you hear, the lot of you? He admits it!
Just pipe down for two minutes, Bert.
But you heard him.
Shut up! We want to hear what he's got to say.
But your car? How did you make it move by itself?
Science, not sorcery, Miss Hawthorne. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up the remote control and makes Bessie honk her horn and flash her headlights.

Dialogue.Line: That's amazing.
I'll be blowed.
And your Mister Magister uses no more magic than that.
You're talking rubbish. The Master's a magician I tell you!
All his feats are based on science. Either ours or the secret science of the Daemons.
Well, there you are. That proves you're talking nonsense. How could he have called him up in the first place except by sorcery?
Well, he uses violent emotions. Fear, hatred, greed.
How?
Well, the emotions of a group of ordinary human beings generate a tremendous charge of psychokinetic energy. This the Master channels for his own purpose.
But that is magic. That's precisely what black magic is.
No, Miss Hawthorne, I'm afraid not.
Are you trying to tell me that the invocations, the rituals, even the sabbat itself are just so much window dressing?
No, no, no, of course not. No, they are essential to generate and control the psionic forces, and to control the Daemon himself.
Look, shouldn't we get over there and sort this Daemon thing out?
How?
Well, I could get the men
Yes?
Well, we could
Exactly. All we can do is wait.
Well, what for?
The energy exchanger. This machine that the Brigadier is building for me. With that I should be able to drain off our visitor's energy. Then perhaps we can sort him out.
Azal, the time for decision draws near. Once more, I demand the power
You demand?
Yes, and why not? Who in the whole galaxy is not my inferior? There is not one creature.
Not even one?
Not one! Save the last of the Daemons.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo is dragged back in, wearing a white gown.

Dialogue.Line: No, please, let me go!
Azal, accept this offering as a token of our fealty. As my will, so mote it be!
As thy will, so mote it be!
Eoh evotay, Azal!
Eoh evotay! Eoh evotay!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Upstairs in the vestry, Yates wakes up, rolls over and gets to his feet. He takes a quick look down the stairs to the cavern then runs outside.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! Doctor!
Hold him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Benton and Miss Hawthorne run to Yates.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! Doctor, it's Jo.
Jo? I thought she was still in the pub?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton unties Yates' hands.

Dialogue.Line: They've got her in the cavern.
What?
That creature's in there. The Master calls him Azal.
Azal? Of course! Azael, the fallen angel.
Walkie talkie. Hello, Brigadier? Are you there?
That you, Doctor?
Over.
Look, they've got Jo. That machine must come through now. Now, do you understand?!
Now!
We're on our way, Doctor.
Good. And put a watch up on that barrow, will you? Just in case the Daemon's ship reactivates.
Will do, Doctor. Over and out. You heard him, Sergeant. Now.
I
That's an order, Sergeant. Now!
Come on, Brigadier. Get a move on.
I'm sorry, Miss Grant, but you are to be sacrificed in a noble cause.
No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The power from the grid is building in the machine, and smoke is starting to come out of it.

Dialogue.Line: It'll never take it, I tell you.
It must. Keep trying.
Right, now some of you that way, but spread out. The rest of you, follow me.
Mister Magister, they're coming, they're coming.
Doctor, help!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master sends Bok out of the cavern.
Where its appearance at the church gate stops the posse in its tracks.

Dialogue.Line: Right, Benton. You keep us covered. We'll get in round the back.
No. We must wait for the Brigadier.
And what about Jo?
We won't help her by committing suicide.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bert gets free of Thorpe and another man, and runs towards the church.

Dialogue.Line: Magister! Magister!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok blocks his way.

Dialogue.Line: No, no. A friend. I'm a friend.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok zaps him into nothingness.

Dialogue.Line: You see? What's going on, Brigadier?
You must hurry!
We're up to the maximum now, Doctor. It's still no good.
You'll have to use the booster.
If you do, sir, she'll blow us all sky high!
We're coming through, Doctor. Over and out. Booster on.
But sir.
Damn it, man. Get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood hesitates so the Brigadier pushes down the lever labelled Boost himself.

Dialogue.Line: O mighty Azal, in the name of Atame, I dedicate this offering!
No, Magister, it's not right!
To do my will shall be the whole of the law.
To do thy will shall be the whole of the law.
It's not right, I tell you.
Obey me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The machine is smoking badly, and the needle is in the red.

Dialogue.Line: Look, it's working!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An archway appears in the heat barrier. The Brigadier tests it with his swagger stick, which smokes but does not burst into flames.

Dialogue.Line: Right, it's still hot, but passable. Right, start up and keep to the tunnel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Brigadier drives his car through the arch, and the troop carriers follow.

Dialogue.Line: Obey me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two men start to lie Jo down on the cleared altar, when Azal holds its head in pain.

Dialogue.Line: Look, what's going on, Brigadier?
We're through, Doctor. Over.
What, all of you?
Yes, but not the machine.
Well, that should have come through first.
Doctor, look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok is staggering around.

Dialogue.Line: The exchanger is working. It's bleeding off the energy.
Come on, man, bring it through! Get a move on!
Sir! Right, Jenkins.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Land Rover and machine drive through the archway.

Dialogue.Line: You can stop worrying, Doctor. We're through.
And about time, too. Now get it over here fast!
Right.
Sir! Sir, I can't stop it! It's running away!
Osgood, out of it! Get down, all of you! Osgood, get down, man!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They clear the vehicle just before the machine goes Boom!

Dialogue.Line: Brigadier? Brigadier, are you all right?
The machine's gone west. Blown itself up. Be with you right away. Over and out.
A fat lot of good that'll do. Right, keep the others back, Captain Yates, I'm going in before that creature recovers.
I'll come with you, Doctor.
Alone!
You can't go in now, sir. You said yourself it would be suicide.
Doctor, wait!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor dodges round the still-staggering Bok and runs for the church. He slams the vestry door shut just as Bok sends an energy bolt at him.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Doctor, I've been expecting you. You've saved me a lot of trouble by coming here. I'm most grateful to you.
Hello, Jo. I cannot tell you how glad I am to see you.
How very touching.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The UNIT convoy arrives in record time for a five mile dash.

Dialogue.Line: Where's the Doctor?
Gone in there, sir.
Then what are we waiting for? Let's get after him.
Wait, sir. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok is watching the newcomers.

Dialogue.Line: What the blazes is that? Some kind of ornament?
Not exactly, sir. Watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Yates throws a rock at Bok, who zaps it into atoms.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I see what you mean. Never mind, we'll soon fix him. Jenkins!
Sir.
Chap with the wings there.  Five rounds rapid.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: No effect, of course.

Dialogue.Line: You realise, of course, that you're a doomed man, Doctor?
Oh, I'm a dead man. I knew that as soon as I came through that door, so you'd better watch out. You see, I've nothing to lose, have I?
Enough! Azal, destroy him!
Who is this?!
My enemy and yours, Azal. Destroy him!
This is the one we spoke of. He too is not of this planet.
He is a meddler and a fool.
He is not a fool, yet he has done a foolish thing coming here. Why did you come?
I came to talk to you.
Talk then.
Certainly. But first let her go.
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Azal sends electricity at the acolytes holding Jo, and they free her.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Are you all right, Jo?
I am now.
You wish to talk?
Yes. I want you to leave this planet while you still can.
You are bold.
Why not? I've got a machine outside that can annihilate you.
You lie.
You've already felt its power.
It is destroyed.
One of them, yes. Not both.
You lie. There was but one.
Doctor?
You have a regard for truth. Why do you lie?
To try and make you listen to me.
Why should I? I see no consequence of value.
Then kill him. Kill him now!
Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Azal aims his hand at the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: No!
If you kill me now, you will wonder throughout eternity whether you should have listened to my words.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The villagers have taken shelter indoors as UNIT continue to try and shoot Bok.

Dialogue.Line: Might as well use a peashooter on four inch armour. Sergeant, get the bazooka set up over there, quick.
Right, sir. Right, you with me.
Well? You waste time. I order you to kill him, Azal!
I command. I do not obey.
But I called you here and you came?
I answered your call because the time was come for my awakening. The time has come for the completion of the experiment or its destruction.
Then fulfill your mission by granting the ultimate power to me. Who else is there strong enough to give these humans the leadership they need?
I seem to remember somebody else speaking like that. What was the bounder's name? Hitler. Yes, that's right, Adolf Hitler. Or was it Genghis Khan?
Azal, I have the will. You yourself said so.
I am still not convinced.
I'm very pleased to hear it.
You wish to see this planet destroyed?
By no means. You see, I have an alternative.
State it.
Leave humanity alone. Just go. You've done enough harm.
We gave knowledge to man.
You certainly did. Thanks to you man can now blow up the world and he probably will. He can poison the water and the very air he breathes. He's already started. He can
Enough! Is man such a failure then? Shall I destroy him?
No! A strong leader can force him to learn.
You are right. I have decided. I shall pass on my power.
O mighty Azal, I thank you.
But not to you. To him.
No! No, I don't want it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok zaps one soldier as the others fire from behind gravestones. Benton brings the bazooka to the retaining wall and takes aim.

Dialogue.Line: Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok is shattered into gravel.

Dialogue.Line: Well done, Sergeant.
Just a minute, sir. Look!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bok reforms from the pieces.

Dialogue.Line: You refuse my gift?
Of course I do! Don't you understand? I want you to leave. I want you to go away and give man a chance to grow up.
I cannot. My instructions are precise. I bequeath my power or I destroy all.
Then you will give your power to me?
I shall. Time is short.
What about him?
He is not rational. He is disruptive. He must be eliminated.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Azal's electricity starts to play over the Doctor's body, then Jo stands in front of him.

Dialogue.Line: No! No, he's a good man! Kill me, not him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo braces herself for the kill shot, but Azal clutches his wrist in pain as his power turns in on himself.

Dialogue.Line: This action does not relate. There is no data. It does not relate. Go! Leave me, all of you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bristling with surplus energy, Azal totters and the humans flee the building.
UNIT continue their assault on Bok until it sits down and assumes its original gargoyle pose.

Dialogue.Line: Cease firing!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jo and the former coven flee the heat-filled church. The Brigadier taps Bok with his stick to check it is now harmless.

Dialogue.Line: Run for it, Brigadier!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Somehow the Master has got ahead of everyone as the church goes KaBOOM!! throwing the runners to the ground. The women come out of their homes and Benton trains his pistol on the Master.

Dialogue.Line: Get up. Don't try anything.
What happened in there, Doctor?
Well, by a ridiculous and foolhardy act of self-sacrifice, Jo here has managed to save us.
I did?
You did. You see, Azal couldn't face an act as irrational and as illogical as her being prepared to give up her life for me. Look, Jo, why don't you go and get out of that ridiculous garb?
Okay.
So what happened?
Well, all his power was turned against himself. You might say he blew a fuse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Boom!

Dialogue.Line: Greyhound Two, come in, please. Over.
Chalmers here at the dig, sir. Are you all right? Over,
Couldn't be better. What's happening?
Big bang at the dig, sir.
The spaceship. Automatic self-destruct, I suppose.
And the barrier's cleared itself. Over.
Good show. We're coming out now with one prisoner. Over and out.
Benton, get ready to move out.
Yes, sir. Right, you lot, you heard the man. The picnic's over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master throws his cope over Benton and runs to Bessie. Benton shoots at him and the Brigadier joins in as the Master drives away.

Dialogue.Line: Stop firing. You'll damage Bessie.
Do you want him to get away?
Don't worry, Bessie'll bring him back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jo is back in her proper clothes as Bessie turns a circle and returns the prisoner.

Dialogue.Line: How on Earth did you do that?
Simple, if you know how.
Right, Benton, get them moved out. And take him with you. Maximum security guard.
Yes, sir. Right, get moving!
And look after him. I want to deal with him later.
Do you, Doctor? You always were an optimist, weren't you.
Thank you for the compliment.
All right, move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Master gets out of Bessie and into the back of a Land Rover, accompanied by six burly soldiers with their rifles pointing at him, and is driven away. The villagers boo him as he leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Listen.
To what?
Yes, the birds are singing again.
Oh, and smell the flowers.
Yes, well, it makes a change from the smell of sulphur, doesn't it?
The May day miracle has happened again. The Earth is born anew.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The morris starts up again.

Dialogue.Line: All under way, sir.
Sergeant, we must do the fertility dance to celebrate.
Oh, no, I'm sorry, ma'am. I'm still rather busy.
Oh, nonsense, Sergeant. Come along.
Come on, Doctor.
Fancy a dance, Brigadier?
It's kind of you, Captain Yates. I think I'd rather have a pint.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The May pole is being wrapped in its ribbons once again.

Dialogue.Line: (dancing) You're right, Jo, there is magic in the world after all.
